items.title: I can identify the two major subdivisions of the nervous system and describe the role of each
items.what: The nervous system divides into the Central Nervous System (CNS), consisting of the brain and spinal cord, and the Peripheral Nervous System (PNS), consisting of all nerves and neurons outside the brain and spinal cord.
items.why: This is the most fundamental distinction in nervous system organisation. Every exam question about neural pathways requires you to identify whether a structure belongs to the CNS or PNS.
items.example: The brain interpreting the taste of food is a CNS function (processing). The nerves carrying taste signals from your tongue to your brain are part of the PNS (transmission).

subtopic.name: The Nervous System Hierarchy
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the two major subdivisions of the nervous system (CNS and PNS), the subdivisions of the PNS (somatic and autonomic), and the three branches of the autonomic nervous system. It also covers afferent, efferent, and interneuron pathways.
subtopic.why: The nervous system hierarchy is the organisational framework for this entire Area of Study. Understanding which structures control which functions is essential for answering scenario-based exam questions about neural pathways, reflexes, and autonomic responses.

items.title: I can describe the somatic nervous system and distinguish between afferent and efferent neurons
items.what: The somatic nervous system controls voluntary skeletal muscle movement and carries sensory information to the CNS. Sensory (afferent) neurons carry information toward the CNS. Motor (efferent) neurons carry commands away from the CNS to muscles.
items.why: Distinguishing afferent from efferent pathways is critical for describing any neural pathway in an exam response. The mnemonic SAME (Sensory = Afferent, Motor = Efferent) can help you remember.
items.example: When you kick a soccer ball, sensory (afferent) neurons carry visual information about the ball's position to your brain, and motor (efferent) neurons carry the command from your brain to your leg muscles to perform the kick.

items.title: I can describe the role of interneurons and where they are located
items.what: Interneurons exist only within the CNS (brain and spinal cord) and relay signals between sensory and motor neurons. They are essential for processing, integration, and decision-making.
items.why: Interneurons are a key component of the spinal reflex arc and are involved in all complex CNS processing. Forgetting to include them in reflex pathway descriptions is a common exam error.
items.example: In a spinal reflex, when you touch a hot surface, an interneuron in the spinal cord relays the signal from the sensory neuron directly to the motor neuron, enabling a rapid withdrawal response.

items.title: I can describe the three subdivisions of the autonomic nervous system
items.what: The autonomic nervous system (ANS) has three subdivisions: the sympathetic NS (prepares the body for vigorous activity or threat), the parasympathetic NS (restores the body to a calm, resting state), and the enteric NS (regulates digestion semi-autonomously in the gut wall).
items.why: Understanding the three ANS subdivisions is essential for explaining the fight-flight-freeze response (Chapter 2), stress physiology, and the gut-brain axis. These concepts appear across Units 3 and 4.
items.example: During a job interview, the sympathetic NS increases your heart rate and sweating. Afterwards, the parasympathetic NS slows your heart rate and promotes digestion. Meanwhile, the enteric NS continues regulating gut motility semi-independently.

items.title: I can explain the concept of autonomic dominance rather than treating the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems as an on/off switch
items.what: Both the sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions are active simultaneously at all times. One division is dominant at any given moment, but the other is still functioning at a lower level. This is called autonomic dominance.
items.why: Treating the two divisions as a simple on/off switch is a common exam error. Using the term 'autonomic dominance' demonstrates precise understanding and earns marks in extended responses.
items.example: Even during intense sympathetic activation while running from danger, the parasympathetic NS is still active at a low level. After escaping, parasympathetic dominance gradually returns, slowing heart rate and resuming digestion.

items.title: I can describe the neural pathway involved in a conscious response
items.what: A conscious response involves awareness and is typically voluntary. The pathway runs from sensory receptors, via afferent neurons to the CNS, where the cerebral cortex processes the information and generates a deliberate response sent via efferent neurons to skeletal muscles.
items.why: Conscious response pathways are a common exam question type. You need to identify every step and name each neuron type to earn full marks.
items.example: You see a ball flying toward you (sensory receptors detect light). Afferent neurons carry the signal to your brain. Your cerebral cortex decides to catch it. Efferent neurons carry the command to your arm muscles, and you raise your hands.

subtopic.name: Conscious and Unconscious Responses
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the difference between conscious (voluntary) and unconscious (involuntary) responses, including the two types of unconscious response: autonomic responses that involve the brainstem, and spinal reflexes that bypass the brain initially.
subtopic.why: This is one of the most frequently examined areas in VCE Psychology. The 2023 exam revealed that 55% of students incorrectly believed all unconscious responses bypass the brain. Understanding the distinction between autonomic responses and spinal reflexes is essential for accurate exam answers.

items.title: I can explain why autonomic responses still involve the brain even though they are unconscious
items.what: Autonomic responses such as heart rate, breathing, and digestion are unconscious and involuntary, but they still involve the brain — specifically the brainstem, which contains regulatory centres for vital functions. Only spinal reflexes bypass the brain initially.
items.why: This is a high-frequency exam error. The 2023 VCAA examiner report explicitly clarified that autonomic responses require both the brain (brainstem) and the spinal cord. Stating that all unconscious responses bypass the brain will cost marks.
items.example: When you exercise, your heart rate increases automatically (unconsciously). This is regulated by the cardiovascular centre in the brainstem, not bypassing the brain. The brainstem detects increased oxygen demand and sends signals via the sympathetic NS to increase heart rate.

items.title: I can describe the spinal reflex arc and the sequence of neuron types involved
items.what: A spinal reflex is a rapid, involuntary response initiated at the spinal cord without initial brain involvement. The sequence is: sensory receptor detects stimulus, afferent neuron carries signal to spinal cord, interneuron relays to motor neuron, efferent neuron signals the muscle, and the withdrawal response occurs. The signal also ascends to the brain simultaneously, but the reflex is already complete.
items.why: Spinal reflex questions appeared in both the 2023 and 2024 exams. In 2024, 64% of students scored zero because they gave generic definitions without linking to the scenario. Always describe the reflex using the specific details from the question.
items.example: Priya touches a hot stovetop. Sensory receptors in her skin detect the heat. An afferent neuron carries the signal to her spinal cord. An interneuron relays it to a motor (efferent) neuron, which signals her arm muscles to contract. She pulls her hand away before her brain even registers the pain.

items.title: I can explain the biological advantage of spinal reflexes in terms of speed
items.what: Spinal reflexes bypass the brain's processing time, enabling the body to respond to threats in 20–50 milliseconds, compared to 150–300 milliseconds for a conscious response. This speed difference can prevent serious injury.
items.why: Understanding why spinal reflexes exist (survival advantage through speed) helps you explain their function in exam scenarios, rather than just describing the pathway mechanically.
items.example: The difference between a spinal reflex (approximately 30 ms) and a conscious response (approximately 200 ms) to touching a hot pan could be the difference between a minor reddening of the skin and a severe burn requiring medical treatment.

items.title: I can distinguish between a spinal reflex and an autonomic response with reference to the brain's role
items.what: A spinal reflex is initiated at the spinal cord without the brain's initial involvement — the brain only receives the signal after the response has already occurred. An autonomic response (e.g. heart rate regulation) is unconscious but still involves the brain, specifically the brainstem, which monitors and regulates the response.
items.why: This distinction is directly tested in VCAA exams and is where many students lose marks. Being able to clearly articulate the difference shows precise understanding of both response types.
items.example: Pulling your hand from a flame is a spinal reflex — the spinal cord initiates the response before the brain is involved. Your heart rate increasing during a scary movie is an autonomic response — the brainstem detects the emotional arousal and signals the heart to beat faster.

items.title: I can label the key structures of a neuron and describe their functions
items.what: A neuron has six key structures: dendrites (receive signals), soma/cell body (integrates signals, contains nucleus), axon (transmits electrical impulses away from soma), myelin sheath (insulates and speeds up transmission), nodes of Ranvier (gaps enabling saltatory conduction), and terminal buttons (store and release neurotransmitters).
items.why: Knowing the structure of a neuron is prerequisite knowledge for understanding synaptic transmission, the action potential, and neural plasticity. Labelling questions appear frequently on exams.
items.example: A motor neuron running from the spinal cord to a toe muscle has dendrites in the spinal cord receiving signals, a soma containing the nucleus, a very long axon (over 1 metre) wrapped in myelin sheath, and terminal buttons that release neurotransmitters onto the muscle.

subtopic.name: Neuron Structure and Synaptic Transmission
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the key structures of a neuron (dendrites, soma, axon, myelin sheath, nodes of Ranvier, terminal buttons) and the step-by-step process of synaptic transmission including the lock-and-key mechanism.
subtopic.why: Neuron structure and synaptic transmission are foundational to all nervous system content. VCAA examiners consistently reward precise technical language when describing these processes, so knowing the correct terminology is essential for earning full marks.

items.title: I can explain that communication within a neuron is electrical and communication between neurons is chemical
items.what: Within a neuron, the action potential (a brief electrical impulse) travels along the axon. Between neurons, neurotransmitters (chemical messengers) carry the signal across the synaptic cleft. Neural information flows in one direction: dendrites, soma, axon, terminal buttons, synapse, next neuron.
items.why: This is a fundamental principle of neural communication. Confusing electrical and chemical transmission, or describing signals as travelling in both directions, are common exam errors.
items.example: When you move your finger, an electrical impulse (action potential) travels along the axon of a motor neuron. When it reaches the terminal button, the signal is converted to a chemical message — neurotransmitters are released across the synapse to the muscle cell.

subtopic.why: Neuron structure and synaptic transmission are foundational to all nervous system content. VCAA examiners consistently reward precise technical language when describing these processes, so knowing the correct terminology is essential for earning full marks.

items.title: I can describe the step-by-step process of synaptic transmission
items.what: Synaptic transmission follows a precise sequence: an action potential arrives at the terminal button, calcium ions enter, synaptic vesicles fuse with the membrane, neurotransmitters are released via exocytosis, they diffuse across the synaptic cleft, and bind to complementary receptor sites on the postsynaptic neuron via the lock-and-key process.
items.why: Detailed knowledge of synaptic transmission is heavily rewarded by VCAA examiners. The difference between a 1-mark and a 3-mark answer is the use of precise terminology such as 'exocytosis,' 'synaptic cleft,' and 'lock-and-key process.'
items.example: A presynaptic neuron fires. The action potential triggers calcium influx at the terminal button. Vesicles release glutamate via exocytosis into the synaptic cleft. Glutamate diffuses across the cleft and binds to complementary receptors on the postsynaptic dendrite (lock-and-key), producing an excitatory effect.

items.title: I can explain the lock-and-key process and why neurotransmitters only bind to specific receptors
items.what: The lock-and-key process describes how each neurotransmitter has a specific molecular shape that must match the shape of the receptor on the postsynaptic neuron, like a key fitting a lock. A neurotransmitter can only produce an effect if it binds to a complementary receptor.
items.why: The lock-and-key concept explains why different neurotransmitters have different effects and why drugs that mimic neurotransmitter shapes can affect neural activity. This links directly to pharmacology content in Unit 4.
items.example: Glutamate has a specific molecular shape that fits glutamate receptors (like NMDA receptors) but does not fit GABA receptors. Similarly, GABA fits GABA receptors but not glutamate receptors. This specificity ensures that excitatory and inhibitory signals remain distinct.

items.title: I can describe the three mechanisms by which neurotransmitters are cleared from the synapse
items.what: After neurotransmitters have bound to receptors, the remaining molecules in the synaptic cleft are cleared by three mechanisms: reuptake (absorbed back into the presynaptic terminal for reuse), enzymatic degradation (broken down by enzymes in the cleft), or diffusion (drifting away from the synapse).
items.why: Understanding neurotransmitter clearance is important for explaining how drugs work. For example, many antidepressants (SSRIs) block the reuptake of serotonin, increasing its availability in the synapse.
items.example: After glutamate is released and binds to postsynaptic receptors, the remaining glutamate molecules are either taken back into the presynaptic neuron (reuptake), broken down by enzymes in the cleft (enzymatic degradation), or drift away (diffusion).

items.title: I can distinguish between excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) and inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSPs)
items.what: An EPSP is a depolarisation of the postsynaptic neuron that makes it more likely to fire an action potential. An IPSP is a hyperpolarisation of the postsynaptic neuron that makes it less likely to fire. Whether an EPSP or IPSP is produced depends on the neurotransmitter and receptor type.
items.why: The EPSP/IPSP distinction is the foundation for understanding how neural activity is regulated. Without this knowledge, you cannot explain summation, the all-or-none principle, or the balance between glutamate and GABA.
items.example: When glutamate binds to a receptor on a postsynaptic neuron, it produces an EPSP — pushing the neuron's charge closer to the firing threshold. When GABA binds to a receptor on the same neuron, it produces an IPSP — pushing the charge further from the threshold.

subtopic.name: Neurotransmitters: Glutamate and GABA
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the roles of glutamate (the brain's primary excitatory neurotransmitter) and GABA (the brain's primary inhibitory neurotransmitter), the difference between EPSPs and IPSPs, and the process of summation and the all-or-none response.
subtopic.why: Glutamate and GABA are the two neurotransmitters specified in the VCE study design for this topic. Understanding their excitatory and inhibitory effects is essential for explaining synaptic plasticity, the stress response, and the biological basis of anxiety and phobia in later units.

items.title: I can explain the role of glutamate as the brain's primary excitatory neurotransmitter
items.what: Glutamate is responsible for approximately 75% of all excitatory transmission in the brain. It produces EPSPs and is essential for learning, memory formation, cognitive functions, and long-term potentiation (LTP) through activation of NMDA receptors. Excess glutamate can cause excitotoxicity, damaging neurons.
items.why: Glutamate is directly linked to LTP and memory formation, making it central to multiple exam topics. Understanding excitotoxicity also connects to neurodegenerative diseases, showing the importance of balance in neural activity.
items.example: When you study new material, glutamate is released at synapses in the hippocampus. It binds to NMDA receptors, producing EPSPs that contribute to LTP — strengthening the synaptic connections that encode the new memory.

subtopic.name: Neurotransmitters: Glutamate and GABA
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the roles of glutamate (the brain's primary excitatory neurotransmitter) and GABA (the brain's primary inhibitory neurotransmitter), the difference between EPSPs and IPSPs, and the process of summation and the all-or-none response.
subtopic.why: Glutamate and GABA are the two neurotransmitters specified in the VCE study design for this topic. Understanding their excitatory and inhibitory effects is essential for explaining synaptic plasticity, the stress response, and the biological basis of anxiety and phobia in later units.

items.title: I can explain the role of GABA as the brain's primary inhibitory neurotransmitter
items.what: GABA is present at approximately 30–40% of all synapses in the brain. It produces IPSPs that reduce neural firing. GABA prevents overexcitation, regulates anxiety by calming the amygdala, promotes sleep, and supports concentration by suppressing irrelevant neural activity. GABA is synthesised from glutamate.
items.why: GABA's role in regulating anxiety connects Unit 3 AOS1 directly to Unit 4 AOS2 (specific phobia). The chain of insufficient GABA leading to unregulated amygdala activity leading to heightened fear has been directly examined in both 2023 and 2024.
items.example: A person with low GABA levels may experience excessive neural firing in the amygdala, leading to heightened anxiety. Benzodiazepines (anti-anxiety medication) work by enhancing GABA's inhibitory effects, increasing the calming influence on neural activity.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the roles of glutamate (the brain's primary excitatory neurotransmitter) and GABA (the brain's primary inhibitory neurotransmitter), the difference between EPSPs and IPSPs, and the process of summation and the all-or-none response.
subtopic.why: Glutamate and GABA are the two neurotransmitters specified in the VCE study design for this topic. Understanding their excitatory and inhibitory effects is essential for explaining synaptic plasticity, the stress response, and the biological basis of anxiety and phobia in later units.

items.title: I can explain the process of summation and the all-or-none response
items.what: Summation is the process by which a postsynaptic neuron integrates all incoming EPSPs and IPSPs from hundreds or thousands of presynaptic neurons simultaneously. If total excitatory input exceeds total inhibitory input enough to reach the neuron's threshold, an action potential fires at full strength (all-or-none principle). There is no partial action potential.
items.why: Summation explains how the brain makes decisions at the cellular level — it is the mechanism by which competing excitatory and inhibitory signals are resolved into a single outcome (fire or not fire).
items.example: A postsynaptic neuron receives 100 EPSPs from glutamate-releasing neurons and 80 IPSPs from GABA-releasing neurons simultaneously. The net excitatory input exceeds the threshold, so the neuron fires a full-strength action potential. If it had received 100 IPSPs instead, the threshold would not be reached and no action potential would occur.

items.title: I can define synaptic plasticity and explain its significance for learning and memory
items.what: Synaptic plasticity is the ability of synaptic connections between neurons to strengthen or weaken over time in response to experience. It is the fundamental neural mechanism underlying learning and memory — when you learn something new, the physical connections between neurons in your brain change.
items.why: Synaptic plasticity is the overarching concept that connects LTP, LTD, sprouting, rerouting, and pruning. Without understanding plasticity, the individual mechanisms lack context.
items.example: A child learning to read activates certain neural pathways repeatedly. Through synaptic plasticity, those pathways strengthen over time, making reading progressively easier and more automatic. Pathways for inefficient reading strategies weaken and are eventually removed.

subtopic.name: Synaptic Plasticity: LTP and LTD
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers synaptic plasticity as the brain's ability to strengthen or weaken synaptic connections in response to experience, including the mechanisms of long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term depression (LTD).
subtopic.why: Synaptic plasticity is the neural basis of learning and memory. LTP and LTD explain how the brain encodes new information, refines skills, and discards unused connections. These concepts are heavily examined and connect to almost every other topic in VCE Psychology.

items.title: I can explain long-term potentiation (LTP) as a long-lasting strengthening of synapses due to repeated stimulation
items.what: LTP is the long-lasting strengthening of synaptic connections between neurons that are frequently co-activated due to repeated stimulation. The complete definition must include three elements: (1) long-lasting, (2) strengthening of a synapse, (3) due to repeated stimulation. At the cellular level, the presynaptic neuron releases more glutamate and the postsynaptic neuron develops more receptor sites (AMPA receptors).
items.why: The 2024 examiner report flagged that 46% of students scored zero on an LTP question because they omitted 'repeated stimulation.' Including all three elements in your definition is essential for full marks.
items.example: When a student practises multiplication tables daily for weeks, the neural pathways for those calculations are repeatedly activated. Through LTP, more glutamate is released and more AMPA receptors develop on postsynaptic neurons, making the pathway easier to activate — so recall becomes faster and more effortless.

subtopic.name: Synaptic Plasticity: LTP and LTD
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers synaptic plasticity as the brain's ability to strengthen or weaken synaptic connections in response to experience, including the mechanisms of long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term depression (LTD).
subtopic.why: Synaptic plasticity is the neural basis of learning and memory. LTP and LTD explain how the brain encodes new information, refines skills, and discards unused connections. These concepts are heavily examined and connect to almost every other topic in VCE Psychology.

items.title: I can explain long-term depression (LTD) as a long-lasting weakening of synapses due to lack of stimulation
items.what: LTD is the long-lasting weakening of synaptic connections that are not regularly activated, resulting from lack of stimulation or prolonged low-level stimulation. AMPA receptors are removed from the postsynaptic membrane, reducing the neuron's sensitivity to glutamate. The connection becomes harder to activate.
items.why: LTD is equally important to learning as LTP. Without LTD, the brain would become overloaded with unnecessary connections. LTD clears unused pathways and allows the brain to allocate resources efficiently. Note that 'depression' here refers to reduced neural activity, not the mental health condition.
items.example: A person who was fluent in French as a child but has not spoken or practised French for 15 years finds it much harder to recall vocabulary and grammar. The neural pathways for French have weakened through LTD due to lack of regular activation.

subtopic.name: Synaptic Plasticity: LTP and LTD
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers synaptic plasticity as the brain's ability to strengthen or weaken synaptic connections in response to experience, including the mechanisms of long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term depression (LTD).
subtopic.why: Synaptic plasticity is the neural basis of learning and memory. LTP and LTD explain how the brain encodes new information, refines skills, and discards unused connections. These concepts are heavily examined and connect to almost every other topic in VCE Psychology.

items.title: I can describe relevant research supporting LTP and synaptic plasticity
items.what: Bliss and Lømo (1973) first demonstrated LTP experimentally by delivering high-frequency electrical stimulation to rabbit hippocampal neurons, finding that synaptic responses were significantly and lastingly enhanced. Maguire et al. (2000) showed London taxi drivers had larger posterior hippocampi correlated with years of navigation experience, demonstrating LTP-driven structural changes in human brains.
items.why: Research evidence strengthens exam responses and demonstrates your ability to link theory to experimental findings. Maguire et al. is the most commonly cited neuroplasticity study in VCE Psychology.
items.example: Maguire found that taxi drivers who had been navigating London for 20 years had significantly larger posterior hippocampi than new drivers. A 2011 follow-up (Woollett and Maguire) tracked trainees over 3–4 years and found hippocampal growth only in those who successfully qualified, confirming that the changes resulted from learning, not pre-existing differences.

subtopic.name: Synaptic Plasticity: LTP and LTD
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers synaptic plasticity as the brain's ability to strengthen or weaken synaptic connections in response to experience, including the mechanisms of long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term depression (LTD).
subtopic.why: Synaptic plasticity is the neural basis of learning and memory. LTP and LTD explain how the brain encodes new information, refines skills, and discards unused connections. These concepts are heavily examined and connect to almost every other topic in VCE Psychology.

items.title: I can describe sprouting as the growth of new dendritic or axonal branches driven by LTP
items.what: Sprouting is the growth of new dendritic or axonal branches to form new synaptic connections. It occurs when neural pathways are frequently activated via LTP, stimulating the neuron to extend additional branches that connect with neighbouring neurons.
items.why: Sprouting explains how the brain builds new networks in response to learning and practice. It is linked to LTP — repeated activation drives the growth of new connections.
items.example: When a person learns to play piano, repeated practice strengthens existing pathways (LTP) and stimulates sprouting — new dendritic branches grow, creating additional connections between the motor cortex, cerebellum, and auditory cortex, supporting increasingly fluid performance.

subtopic.name: Neural Modifications: Sprouting, Rerouting, and Pruning
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers three structural modifications driven by synaptic plasticity: sprouting (growth of new connections via LTP), rerouting (redirection of pathways, often after injury, via LTP), and pruning (elimination of unused connections via LTD).
subtopic.why: These three modifications are the observable structural outcomes of LTP and LTD. Exam questions frequently ask you to explain how synaptic plasticity modifies neural connections, and simply listing the three terms without linking them to LTP or LTD will not earn full marks.

items.title: I can describe rerouting as the redirection of neural connections to create alternative pathways
items.what: Rerouting is the redirection of existing neural connections to create alternative pathways, often around damaged or dysfunctional neurons. It is a key mechanism of recovery after brain injury and is driven by LTP in the surviving neurons that form new connections.
items.why: Rerouting explains how the brain can partially recover function after injury, such as stroke. Understanding this mechanism helps you answer exam scenarios about rehabilitation and brain damage recovery.
items.example: After a stroke damages neurons in the motor cortex controlling the right hand, intensive physiotherapy repeatedly activates surviving neurons near the damaged area. Through LTP and rerouting, these neurons form new connections that create alternative pathways to the hand muscles, partially restoring movement.

subtopic.name: Neural Modifications: Sprouting, Rerouting, and Pruning
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers three structural modifications driven by synaptic plasticity: sprouting (growth of new connections via LTP), rerouting (redirection of pathways, often after injury, via LTP), and pruning (elimination of unused connections via LTD).
subtopic.why: These three modifications are the observable structural outcomes of LTP and LTD. Exam questions frequently ask you to explain how synaptic plasticity modifies neural connections, and simply listing the three terms without linking them to LTP or LTD will not earn full marks.

items.title: I can describe pruning as the elimination of unused synaptic connections driven by LTD
items.what: Pruning is the elimination of weak, unused synaptic connections. It is driven by LTD — connections that are not regularly activated weaken progressively until they are removed entirely. Pruning is essential for efficient brain function, summarised as 'use it or lose it.'
items.why: Pruning is not negative — it refines neural networks so the brain operates efficiently. It is particularly important during childhood and adolescence, when the brain eliminates connections not reinforced by experience while strengthening those that are.
items.example: Infants have far more synaptic connections than adults. During childhood, a child who regularly practises reading strengthens those pathways (LTP), while connections for skills they rarely use weaken and are pruned (LTD). The result is a more efficient, specialised neural network.

subtopic.name: Neural Modifications: Sprouting, Rerouting, and Pruning
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers three structural modifications driven by synaptic plasticity: sprouting (growth of new connections via LTP), rerouting (redirection of pathways, often after injury, via LTP), and pruning (elimination of unused connections via LTD).
subtopic.why: These three modifications are the observable structural outcomes of LTP and LTD. Exam questions frequently ask you to explain how synaptic plasticity modifies neural connections, and simply listing the three terms without linking them to LTP or LTD will not earn full marks.

items.title: I can connect sprouting, rerouting, and pruning to LTP and LTD in an integrated exam response
items.what: Sprouting and rerouting result from LTP — they involve the growth and strengthening of neural connections through repeated activation. Pruning results from LTD — it involves the weakening and elimination of connections due to lack of use. In any learning scenario, all three modifications may occur simultaneously.
items.why: Exam questions that ask you to 'explain how synaptic plasticity modifies neural connections' require you to link each modification to its underlying mechanism (LTP or LTD). Simply listing the three modifications without this connection will not earn full marks.
items.example: A student learning to drive strengthens the neural pathways for steering, braking, and mirror-checking through LTP, with new connections sprouting between relevant brain regions. Incorrect habits (e.g. looking down at the gearstick) weaken through LTD and are eventually pruned. If the student had a prior injury, rerouting via LTP may help alternative pathways compensate.

items.title: I can apply knowledge of nervous system functioning to novel scenarios in exam-style questions
items.what: Applying nervous system knowledge means tracing a scenario through multiple levels: identifying which NS structures are involved, describing the neural pathways, explaining how neurotransmitters contribute, and connecting to synaptic plasticity where relevant. Responses must always reference the specific details given in the scenario.
items.why: The most common reason students lose marks is providing generic definitions without connecting them to the scenario. VCAA examiners reward responses that link content to the specific context described in the question.
items.example: For a scenario about a person learning to cook: the somatic NS carries sensory information (sight, touch, smell) to the CNS. The brain generates voluntary motor commands to skeletal muscles. With repeated practice, LTP strengthens the relevant pathways (more glutamate, more receptors), sprouting creates new connections, and LTD prunes inefficient techniques — until cooking becomes near-automatic.
